awd_titl_txt: Build and Broaden 2.0: Understanding Barriers to Equity in Public Safety Policies
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). The goal of the proposed research is to gain new insights into current barriers to equity in public safety policy. The proposed research employs mixed-method approaches to better understand psychological characteristics and their relation to changes in public safety policy aimed at greater levels of equity. Disparities are present in virtually all aspects of public safety, including exposure to neighborhood violence, emergency response times and dispatch, overall enforcement, prosecution and conviction rate, pretrial detention bail and bond levels, and sentencing. This study will employ mixed-method approaches focused on the population of people who appear to benefit from inequity, as well as the barriers to their acceptance of new policies and practices. This is important because it deviates from most inquiry, which tends to pathologize marginalized communities through research that centers suffering as opposed to inequity, with little attention given to potential sources.  
 
The project will use a three-phased research approach. Phase 1 will explore the characteristics (e.g., values, age, race, personality, and attitudes) that predict opposition to changes in public safety policies and funding, across five areas of change, using a recently passed series of policy changes in state-level public safety policy.  Phase 2 will take a closer look at the relationships between values, attitudes, characteristics and resistance to change among distinct groups of state residents in order to better understand overlapping and unique barriers to change across subgroups. Phase 3 will consist of qualitative interviews with a subset of survey participants from the first two phases to identify the theories that best explain support for and resistance to these policy changes. Therefore, this study of the barriers to reducing inequities through policy changes may increase understanding of barriers to attaining public-safety equity nationally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Principal Investigators: Ericka Mingo PhD & Judah Viola PhD

Project Dir: Jaimelee Behrendt-Mihalski, PhD

Summary:

In 2021, National Louis University received a $300,000 Build and Broaden 2:0 award entitled “Understanding the Psychological Barriers to Equity in Public Safety Policies”

Racial and ethnic disparities and inequities abound within our criminal justice and public safety system, leading to mass incarceration and suffering. Disparities are present in virtually all aspects of public safety (Kovera, 2019) from exposure to neighborhood violence (Berg, 2014), and emergency response times and dispatch (David & Harrington, 2010), to laws that harm communities of color at greater levels (Kerr, 2016).

Much of the extant inquiry tends to focus on marginalized communities. Such narrow focus can lead to gaps in the understanding of the psychological roots of the unfair and unethical practices currently in place. Populations resistant to equitable policy shifts are often understudied. Seeking understanding of opposition to equitable public safety policy, offers important data for future policy making, public awareness, and education measures.

The three-part study employed a mixed-method, statewide representative survey (quantitative) followed by one-on-one semi-structured interviews (qualitative) approaches to better understand who is most resistant to equitable public safety policy and why.

The research involved a diverse team of faculty and graduate students. National Louis University (NLU), is dedicated to advancing equity, particularly within our graduate programs. The project emerged from our Community Psychology Ph.D. program which emphasizes research practices that avoid further marginalizing disadvantaged populations.

Through the mentoring of the Principal Investigators, the project director and graduate researchers gained skills related to research ethics, developing and delivering national, and international conference presentations, new methodologies for, Meta comment data synthesis for the purpose of understanding and measuring the diversity of Facebook reactions as a potential indicator of personal and collective attitudes towards equity.

Bot Detection

To ensure reliable data, we developed a multi-step process to detect bots and exclude bot responses from our analysis. These protocols proved to be a significant asset in ensuring a quality data sample for our study. Across 18 rounds of data collection, our online recruitment strategy produced over 15,000 responses. After the implementation of bot detection protocols developed by our team, 14,411 of those responses were eliminated as fraudulent or bot responses, leaving us with 589 responses that were determined to be valid.

Key Outcomes & Findings

We found that a larger majority of the sample supported equity-based reforms focused on increasing individual resident’s rights (>70%) as well as police accountability (>75%) than would have been expected based upon media representations.

 One distinct group of resistors to equitable public safety policy shared similar characteristics:

This group (n=131) were predominantly:

●      "Conservative" or "strongly conservative" on economic and social issues

●      Positive in their perceptions of police 

●      Low in trust of government officials

●      White (80%)

●      People who endorsed the statement "efforts toward racial equity in this country have gone too far." (82%)

●      People who endorsed the statement "people see racial discrimination where it really does not exist." (92%)

In addition, linear regression analysis revealed significant barriers to the acceptance of equity-focused policies among the resistor group:

●      Lower government trust was most predictive of resistance to increased         detainee, prisoner, and citizens’ rights.

●      Social conservatism, low government trust, support for police, and greater religiosity, predicted resistance to increased police transparency and accountability.

●      Less than 15% (n = 131) supported court reforms aimed at decreasing racial biases and increasing racial equity (e.g., the elimination of cash bail).

 

Qualitative analysis of interview data revealed that participants who were the most resistant to equity-focused policy change demonstrated significant:

●      Concerns that policy changes will not have intended effects

●      Exposure to negative media

●      Lack of knowledge of the specific policies enacted

●      Distrust of government

●      Fear of losing resources and power

●      Fear of becoming less safe

●      Peer network influences

●      Racial prejudices 

NSF European Research Council Collaboration

Our research team partnered with the University of Uppsala in Sweden’s Department of Peace and Conflict Research. Our senior research team traveled to Uppsala Sweden to exchange outcomes and methodologies towards best practice across our shared research goals. After a successful exchange, a member of the Uppsala team traveled to Chicago in July 2023 for continued collaboration.

Additionally, we expanded our collaboration to a team at the University of Kent in the UK. Both research collaborations engaged faculty and graduate students at National Louis University, the University of Uppsala, and the University of Kent.

Broader Impacts

Understanding psychological barriers to equity in public safety is an essential component of support for local, state, and national efforts to eliminate inequalities in public safety policies. Our project developed an empirically grounded knowledge base towards future implementation of equity and justice in public safety policy.
